title: The First Hymn - Has it really been given to the church?
description:
A newly revived ancient Christian hymn, brought to life by John Dickson’s The First Hymn project and reimagined by Chris Tomlin and Ben Fielding, has been presented as a "gift to the church." But is it truly a gift if churches must pay to sing it in worship?

For more detail on the commercialization of the worship indu

title: Does Canon Pay the Bills Biblically?
description: A common misconception regarding most Christian ministries is that, if you simply ask them for free access to some ministry content they produce, they’ll give it quickly and happily, especially to missionaries or the needy in other countries. Sometimes people use this as a justification for the Jesus trade, saying that
description_html:
A common misconception regarding most Christian ministries is that, if you simply ask them for free access to some ministry content they produce, they’ll give it quickly and happily, especially to missionaries or the needy in other countries. Sometimes people use this as a justification for the Jesus trade, saying that if they are willing to give when people ask, then it’s OK not to freely give in the first place. But even this kind of limited generosity is rare. So we tried asking Canon Press, which was founded as a literature ministry. On their own website they say explicitly that their function is to outfit Christians everywhere with tools to live like Christ is Lord over every aspect of life. This is our email interaction.

Christian ministry defined biblically: https://sellingjesus.org/articles/defining-ministry
Recommended reading: https://sellingjesus.org/learn/profiles#jada-the-publishing-ceo
https://sellingjesus.org/learn/profiles#joe-the-author
Recommended satire video: https://youtu.be/hdoxobictFY

@CanonPress

title: Is Bible Project's Funding Biblical?
description: Although we disagree with Bible Project on some key theological issues and their stance on intellectual property, we are encouraged by the example they have set in freely giving ministry through the biblical support model. God has blessed their decision not to sell biblical teaching, but rather fund it through the free
description_html:
Although we disagree with Bible Project on some key theological issues and their stance on intellectual property, we are encouraged by the example they have set in freely giving ministry through the biblical support model. God has blessed their decision not to sell biblical teaching, but rather fund it through the free generosity of God's people. They serve as a model in this respect for others who doubt that God can fund large (or small) ministries solely through donations. We would encourage the Bible Project to delve more deeply into the vast array of biblical teaching on the issue of money and ministry, and apply biblical principles not only to their model of giving resources, but also to their perspective on intellectual property and copyright. Learn more about a biblical approach to copyright with the following three links:

Articles: https://sellingjesus.org/learn under the section "Copyright and Licensing"
Recommended reading: https://sellingjesus.org/learn/resources#category-2
How Copyright Hurts the World video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nKqUckG4bmA

@bibleproject

title: Is It Ever OK to Peddle God's Word? Reacting to Mike Winger on 2 Corinthians 2:17
description:
Mike Winger says that he would never peddle God's Word to enrich himself, but would he do it to pay the bills? Is it ok to sell Jesus as long as it's not for a certain arbitrarily "large" amount of money? Is it ok to sell Jesus if our family will starve if we don't? Conley Owens explains why not.

The article on 2 Cori

title: Truth for Sale - the sad irony about this book that no one noticed
description: In this video we discuss the irony of Megan Basham's new book "Shepherds for Sale" being sold for profit. While the book exposes the dangers of progressive agendas infiltrating the Church, the author has put it behind a paywall, which is unintentionally cruel and illogical, contrary to Scripture, and casts doubt on the
description_html:
In this video we discuss the irony of Megan Basham's new book "Shepherds for Sale" being sold for profit. While the book exposes the dangers of progressive agendas infiltrating the Church, the author has put it behind a paywall, which is unintentionally cruel and illogical, contrary to Scripture, and casts doubt on the author's sincerity. Commodifying the truth carries sad consequences. Instead, we are called by Jesus to freely give (Matthew 10:8). There are simple, clear alternatives to peddling Christian exhortation. Let’s pray that this is the last time someone tries to sound the alarm and inspire reform within the Church by SELLING their message.

How to Publish a Book That's Truly Freely Given: https://copy.church/publish/book/

title: The Elephant in the Sanctuary - Exposing the Jesus Trade's Inconsistencies
description:
Let's chat! 

Here's the video with the skit I'm talking about: https://youtu.be/XKf6-PZ6PB8

It’s super crucial for all believers to be as consistent as possible in their theology and practice, and this skit points out glaring inconsistencies in both of those things when it regards the commercialization of Christianit
description_html:
Let's chat!

Here's the video with the skit I'm talking about: https://youtu.be/XKf6-PZ6PB8

It’s super crucial for all believers to be as consistent as possible in their theology and practice, and this skit points out glaring inconsistencies in both of those things when it regards the commercialization of Christianity. So far, with thousands of copies of "The Dorean Principle" distributed, and with thousands of hours of our content being consumed, and with many conversations we’ve had with people of diverse backgrounds who even have PhD ‘s and are professors in seminaries, we've never found anyone who can answer the logical inconsistencies we've pointed out clearly or satisfactorily. But we have heard plenty of sophistry when we ask simple questions about the Jesus trade, like: Is it ok to be peddlers of God’s Word in some contexts and not others? Why is it ok to charge to hear a sermon at a conference but not at church? The answers we usually get are basically like saying, “Idolatry just depends on the context. It’s ok to worship idols as long as it’s not inside your local church.” This is why no one has offered any rebuttal to our call for reform in this area. No one is willing to debate because, we suspect, they know that they have no argument.

Want to have a friendly public discussion/debate about what we're asserting? We'd love to hear from you! Please write to us at sellingjesus.org@gmail.com .

Please consider learning more at:

https://sellingjesus.org/
https://thedoreanprinciple.org/
https://copy.church/

Follow:

https://www.facebook.com/sellingjesus.org
https://twitter.com/Selling_Jesus
https://open.spotify.com/show/2dDRm550aeja4a8vdtHEck

[See any ads? YouTube sometimes shows them, but they are outside our control. This channel will never be monetized, and you can also watch here ad-free: https://lets.church/channel/sellingjesus . Read our position on ads at https://sellingjesus.org/articles/ads ]
